content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of the continuous function <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown above for <math alttext="negative 3 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is twice differentiable, except at <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function with <math alttext="f of 0 equals, negative 1 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and derivative given by <math alttext="f prime of x equals, open parenthesis, x squared, minus five fourths, close parenthesis, times, e to the x power"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Classify each critical point as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither. Justify your answers.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of the continuous function <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown above for <math alttext="negative 3 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is twice differentiable, except at <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function with <math alttext="f of 0 equals, negative 1 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and derivative given by <math alttext="f prime of x equals, open parenthesis, x squared, minus five fourths, close parenthesis, times, e to the x power"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Classify each critical point as the location of a relative minimum, a relative maximum, or neither. Justify your answers.

(b) Find all values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which the graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a point of inflection. Give reasons for your answers.

(c) Fill in the missing entries in the table below to describe the behavior of <math alttext="g prime "><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and <math alttext="g double prime "><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> on the interval <math alttext="negative 3 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Indicate Positive or Negative. Give reasons for your answers. <math alttext="The figure presents a partially completed 4 row table, with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “g of x.” The heading for row 3 is “g prime of x.” The heading for row 4 is “g double prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x equals negative 3. g of x is 0. g prime of x is 0. g double prime of x is 0. Column 2. Negative 3 is less than x, is less than 0. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is a blank cell. g double prime of x is a blank cell. Column 3. x equals 0. g of x is 2. g prime of x is 2. g double prime of x is Undefined. Column 4. 0 is less than x, is less than 3. g of x is Positive. g prime of x is a blank cell. g double prime of x is a blank cell. Column 5. x equals 3. g of x is 4. g prime of x is 0. g double prime of x is 0. "></math> <math> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="4em 0.05em 4em 5em 5em 5em 4em" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"> <mtr> <mtd> <mi>x</mi> </mtd> <mtd> <mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace> </mtd> <mtd> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </mtd> <mtd> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> <mo><</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo><</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>0</mn> <mo><</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo><</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mtd> </mtr> <mtr> <mtd> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mtd> <mtd> <mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>0</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mtext>Positive</mtext> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>2</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mtext>Positive</mtext> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>4</mn> </mtd> </mtr> <mtr> <mtd> <msup> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>′</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mtd> <mtd> <mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>0</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn></mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>2</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn></mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>0</mn> </mtd> </mtr> <mtr> <mtd> <msup> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>″</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mtd> <mtd> <mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>0</mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn></mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mtext>Undefined</mtext> </mtd> <mtd> <mn></mn> </mtd> <mtd> <mn>0</mn> </mtd> </mtr> </mtable> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>

(d) Let <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, f of x, times, g of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing or decreasing at <math alttext="x equals 0 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

topic.text: 5.3: Determining Intervals on Which a Function Is Increasing or Decreasing

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
